content:
Hi! I like the logic mixing digit parity and position.
However, there is a mismatch between the description and the test cases regarding odd digits.
The text says 'absolute value' (e.g., 1 - 5 = 4), but your tests expect a cyclic modulo result (e.g., 1 - 5 to 6).
While Python's % operator handles negative wrapping automatically, this logic will fail in C++, or JS where the result would be -4 or 4.
I suggest updating the description to: 'For odd digits, use the difference between the digit and its position. If the result is negative, wrap it around (e.g., -1 becomes 9).' or something equivalent.

EDIT: The fun thing is that in your Python solution, ABS() isn't necessary ;)

Goal
* Please add at the beginning:

<<This clash is in Reverse mode only.>>

Stub generator
* Please change 180 to 9.

Cases
* Validator 6: Please use 163258749 (from Validator 7) instead so that it's more similar to Test 6.

* Validator 7: Please modify the case to be similar to Test 7 but slightly different.

Thanks.

Thanks for your comment!
I have updated the tests and I open the contribution to by played with all categories of Clash.

Hello! Thanks a lot for your comment. 
I have clarified the description of the expected modulo. I hope this is clearer.

Nice ! Just a quick tip on the English translation:

- Replace "his position" with "its position" 
- Replace "Rotular dial" with "Cyclic behavior" or say the values "wrap around" (e.g. "For all cases, if the obtained value is a negative number or has more than one digit, it wraps around (cyclic modulo). For example: -1 becomes 9, -4 becomes 6, 12 becomes 2...")

This will make the instructions crystal clear :)
Pefect for me! Don't forget to switch the status from WIP to Public so we can give it a 'thumbs up'! :)

Thank you. Additional changes are required as modes other than Reverse have been enabled:

Goal
* Please change as follows:
  â€¢ entry => input
  â€¢ For each => For each digit
  â€¢ his => its
  â€¢Â position and => position (begins at 1) and
  â€¢ a even => an even
  â€¢ a odd => an odd
  â€¢ mod10 of this digit plus digits position => (digit plus position) mod 10
  â€¢ mod10 of this digit minus digits position => (digit minus position) mod 10
  â€¢ (the position begins at 1) => [delete the whole sentence]

* Please add at the end:

Output the resultant digits concatenated together.

Output
* Please change "Another" to "The transformed".

Constraints
* Please add:

The input contains 1 to 9 digits.

Thanks again.

A few more fixes:

Goal
* Please change "his" to "its".

Input
* Please change "Line1" to "Line 1".

Output
* Please change "Line1" to "Line 1".

Constraints
* Please remove the second constraint. The first constraint is sufficient, since the length of [[R]] must be the same as the length of [[S]].

* Please revise the first constraint as:

1 â‰¤ length of [[S]] â‰¤ 9

Stub generator
* Please change "seriesOfDigits" to "S" for consistency. Alternatively, change "S" to "seriesOfDigits" in all other sections.

Thank you.

I made the changes.
I just let the name "seriesOfDigits" in the stub generator because it can be a tip for the reverse mode.
Thanks for your returns, it's my first contribution and all are very helpfull !

No problem!

As you choose to keep "seriesOfDigits", please change "S" to "seriesOfDigits" in the Input and Constraints sections.

Thanks! So I changed the stub generator...
Is it possible to give more examples than the only one automatically generated ?

No, it's not possible.

For Fastest and Shortest modes, players can look up the other cases if they want. You may also include more examples in the Goal section, but that's only advisable if some explanation is included at the same time (instead of just examples).

For Reverse mode, all cases automatically appear where the statement is usually shown for the other modes.
It's very clear! Thank you very much!
